Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A uniform sample of Kepler eclipsing binaries as benchmark stars to constrain stellar models and evolution at the bottom of the main sequence
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research program will improve our understanding of low-mass stars (those with less than 80% of the Sun's mass). The team will obtain extremely precise measurements of the masses and radii of nearly 200 eclipsing binary stars. These measurements will drive improvements in theoretical models of stars. These models are used across a wide range of astrophysical disciplines, and they are particularly important for characterizing the tremendous number of exoplanets that astronomers are discovering. Accurate models of stars are needed to evaluate the habitability of Earth mass planets, and the results from this program will be particularly timely as the next generation of exoplanet searches begins explicitly targeting low-mass stars. This Penn State and Villanova collaboration involves undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers in all facets of the research, and members of both teams actively participate in public outreach events.

The primary objective of this program is to measure the mass and radius of binary stars with precision better than 3%, while also characterizing the stars' compositions. This measurement precision is necessary to address well recognized discrepancies for low-mass stars of 5-15% between predictions of current models and the handful of existing measurements. These measurements are achieved through the combination of ultra-precise photometry from NASA's Kepler observatory and extensive high-resolution ground-based spectroscopy from near-infrared and visible wavelength spectrographs (APOGEE, HYDRA, HRS) that have been collected by the team. Data are analyzed with cutting-edge algorithms for light-curve modelling (PHOEBE), multi-dimensional radial velocity measurements (TODCOR/TRICOR), and Markov Chain Monte Carlo techniques for assessing robust and repeatable parameters and parameter uncertainties. Results from this program will more than double the number of low-mass stars with both precision mass and radius measurements, and with spectroscopically determined compositions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eclipsing binary stars are one of the cornerstones of stellar astrophysics. They have long served as principal gauges of fundamental stellar properties and distances. Thanks to the alignment of the orbital plane with the line of sight, eclipses allow us to determine stellar radii to better than a few percent and provide us with an accurate estimate of the temperature ratio between the components. Binarity also provides us with dynamical masses by way of spectroscopy. For systems where both stars are visible (double-lined spectroscopic binaries, or SB2s), we thus get all fundamental stellar parameters: masses, radii, temperatures and luminosities. The project focused on a subset of eclipsing binary stars observed photometrically by NASA's Kepler satellite and followed up spectroscopically by the Hobby Eberly Telescope and Sloan's APOGEE instrument.

The studied subset of eclipsing binaries included:

  • equal mass components: they stem from a particularly interesting and poorly understood formation channel that favors masses equal to within 1%. We were able to confirm that there is an excess of these equal mass components compared to other mass ratios: equal mass binaries occur twice as likely as non-equal mass binaries.
  • low mass systems: they are difficult to study because of the typically low contrast between the two components, and are extremely important because the theoretical models predict smaller radii. We were able to confirm the discrepancy between the predicted and observed radii: observed low-mass stars have radii that are about 10% larger than predicted by theory.
  • highly eccentric systems: short-period, high eccentricity systems are interesting because tidal forces lead to efficient circularization of their orbits and synchronization of the components' spins. We were able to detect strong apsidal motion in 2 eccentric systems, indicative of strong tidal interaction that invalidates the assumptions of point-mass dynamics.
  • occulting systems: these extreme radius-ratio systems combine a main-sequence dwarf and a red giant. They are particularly interesting because of the evolutionary aspect of stellar lifetimes: the main sequence star still burns hydrogen in its core, while the red giant evolved off the main sequence. Given that both stars are of the same age, this places constraints on the evolutionary codes. We found no discrepancy between our modeling results and evolutionary code predictions.

Beyond specific results, the main deliverable of this project is a largely autonomous pipeline that can model light and radial velocity data simultaneously. It is based on the PHOEBE modeling code, probabilistic sampling and Gaussian processes to account for the noise model. The pipeline is currently standalone, but it will be incorporated in the upcoming version of PHOEBE that is scheduled for release in December 2019. The code is fully open-source, licensed under the General Public License, so everyone can use and modify it freely.

An obvious future direction for the project is to increase the sample by including more eclipsing binary stars that were observed by both Kepler and APOGEE. The current number of such objects is ~100. This would further test and potentially strengthen the statistical results derived within the scope of this project.
